content: The Act titled "Identity Theft and Assumption Deterrence Act of 1998" is based on Congress's authority to regulate commerce and make necessary laws. It addresses identity theft. The Act "Identity Theft and Assumption Deterrence Act of 1998" amends Section 1028(a) of title 18, United States Code to include knowingly transferring or using another person's identification without lawful authority to commit unlawful activities. Penalties under Section 1028(b) are also amended. The Act "Identity Theft and Assumption Deterrence Act of 1998" amends Section 1028(a) of title 18, United States Code to include new offenses related to the transfer or use of means of identification, with penalties amended accordingly. The Act "Identity Theft and Assumption Deterrence Act of 1998" amends Section 1028(a) of title 18, United States Code to include new offenses related to the transfer or use of means of identification, with penalties amended accordingly. The amendments include fines, imprisonment up to 20 years, or both for offenses related to drug trafficking, crimes of violence, or repeat convictions. Additionally, forfeiture of personal property used in committing the offense is also included. The Act "Identity Theft and Assumption Deterrence Act of 1998" introduces penalties for offenses related to the transfer or use of means of identification, including fines, imprisonment up to 20 years, and forfeiture of personal property used in the offense. Amendments to Section 1028 of title 18, United States Code specify that the prohibited actions must involve interstate or foreign commerce, or the transportation of identification documents through the mail. The definition of 'document-making implement' and 'identification document' under Section 1028 of title 18, United States Code, is clarified to include specific tools and documents used for identification purposes. The term 'means of identification' includes any name, number, or unique biometric data that can be used to identify an individual, as defined in Section 1028 of title 18, United States Code. The term 'means of identification' includes any name, number, or unique biometric data that can be used to identify an individual. This also encompasses unique electronic identification numbers, addresses, routing codes, telecommunication identifying information, access devices, and personal identification cards issued by State or local governments. The term 'produce' includes altering, authenticating, or assembling. The term 'State' includes any State of the United States, the District of Columbia, the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico, and any other commonwealth, possession, or territory of the United States. Additionally, Section 1028 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include provisions for attempts and conspiracies to commit offenses under this section. The amendment to Section 1028 of title 18, United States Code, includes provisions for attempts and conspiracies to commit offenses under this section, with corresponding penalties. Additionally, forfeiture procedures for property related to this section will follow the guidelines of the Comprehensive Drug Abuse Prevention and Control Act of 1970. The amendment to Section 1028 of title 18, United States Code clarifies that a single identification document with multiple means of identification will be considered as one means of identification. Conforming amendments are made to Chapter 47 of title 18 to reflect this change. SEC. 4. AMENDMENT OF FEDERAL SENTENCING GUIDELINES FOR OFFENSES UNDER SECTION 1028. The United States Sentencing Commission will review and amend the Federal sentencing guidelines to establish appropriate penalties for offenses under section 1028 of title 18, United States Code. Factors for consideration include the number of victims and means of identification involved in the offense. The United States Sentencing Commission will review and amend the Federal sentencing guidelines to establish penalties for offenses under section 1028 of title 18, United States Code. Factors for consideration include the number of means of identification involved, the value of the loss to any individual, the range of conduct covered by the offense, and the adequacy of sentencing enhancements to ensure punishment for egregious conduct. The United States Sentencing Commission will consider various factors when reviewing and amending Federal sentencing guidelines for offenses under section 1028 of title 18, United States Code. These factors include the adequacy of penalties to ensure punishment for the most egregious conduct, the impact of statutory maximum penalties on sentencing guidelines, the alignment of guidelines with the purposes of sentencing, and any other relevant factors deemed appropriate by the Commission. SEC. 5. CENTRALIZED COMPLAINT AND CONSUMER EDUCATION SERVICE FOR VICTIMS OF IDENTITY THEFT. The Federal Trade Commission will establish procedures within a year to log complaints from individuals who believe their identification has been stolen, provide information to them, and refer complaints to relevant entities, including consumer reporting agencies and law enforcement. The Federal Trade Commission will refer complaints of identity theft to consumer reporting agencies and law enforcement for potential action. Authorization of appropriations is provided for the implementation of this section. SEC. 6. Technical amendments to Title 18, United States Code include changes related to criminal forfeiture procedures and the inclusion of economic espionage and theft of trade secrets as predicate offenses for wire interception. Section 105(b) of the Ethics in Government Act of 1978 is amended to allow for redaction of reports filed by individuals described in specific sections of the Act if revealing personal information could endanger them. The redaction is only permitted to protect the individual and must be maintained as long as the danger exists. The Administrative Office of the United States Courts is required to submit an annual report on the operation of this provision to the Committees on the Judiciary of the House of Representatives and the Senate. The Judicial Conference, in consultation with the Department of Justice, will issue regulations for redaction of reports filed under the Ethics in Government Act of 1978 to protect individuals from threats. An annual report must be submitted to Congress detailing the number of redacted reports, individuals affected, and types of threats. This provision expires on December 31, 2001.
